dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move across smoldering embers and reach a small grass fire. Dirt is thrown over the flames before a BOOT finish stamping them out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We're just lucky it didn't reach the trees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move up two dirty pairs of overalls to find HENRY and GEIN sweating away as they continue shovelling out the flames. Both are in their forties and wearing flannel shi Ed wears an Elmer Fudd hat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's gonna be a lot more jobs at that factory by Milwaukee come June. I could put in a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave us, Henry. She needs both

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you stop being a momma's boy for one second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry looks at Ed and he shrinks back.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to hurt you but Jesus you got to live your own life someday. That woman can take care of her own goddamn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLANG. Henry is hit by the shovel in the back of the head goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed steps slowly forward and puts down the shovel. The loo his face isn't anger. It's BLANK. He pulls at the flaps o his Elmer Fudd hat... then calmly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pans until we discover :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in his trademark black Mariani suit. He's been watching t whole thing, standing in the smouldering field only a few feet away, holding a rose-patterned cup and saucer of tea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a sip and turns to address the camera --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places his cup daintily back on the saucer.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brother has been slaying brother since Cain and Abel, yet even I did not see that coming. I was as blind-sided as poor Henry over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances back over at the murder scene.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Apparently the authorities shared my naivete and believed the young man's tale that Henry fell and hit his head on a stone and died of smoke asphyxiation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs: `Who would've thought it?'

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course if they hadn't believed him, Ed never would have had the opportunity to commit the heinous acts for which he became famous... and we wouldn't have our little movie. Instead, we'd have more nice, safe, predictable ones like these...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from various Technicolor Films of the era: Peyton Place, Lana Turner and Betty Field. Pillow Talk with Doris Day a Rock Hudson. A Summer Place with Sandra Dee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mere Technicolor baubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shudders with distaste. As if on cue the sky THUNDERS LOUDLY above him. He looks up and from behind the tree st produces an umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah. A bit of doom and gloom. Now, that's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hitch opens his brolly and the RAIN starts to bucket d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Equally torrential rain lit up by rotating KLEIG LIGHTS a they scan a MARQUEE: "WORLD PREMIERE! NORTH BY NORTHWEST. DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK." JOSTLING CROWDS run the le of the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PUDGY HAND discreetly squeezes a tiny, delicate one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step out into a sea of FLASHBULBS. Hitch basks in the limelight while Alma, his razor-sharp, charming wife of o 30 years stands in the background, uncomfortable with all attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock's agent LEW WASSERMAN, 45, dynamic, charismatic comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing is going to be gigantic. I wish I had twenty percent of the take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew hustles them through the throng of REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS under their BLACK UMBRELLAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does tonight's incredible reaction surprise you, Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, when I was planning North by Northwest I could already hear the screams and laughter. (then, to a BEAUTIFUL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde fan, holding out her autograph book, shakes he head `no' and giggles.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters crack up. Alma manages a polite smile as Le helps her into the limo, leaving Hitchcock alone for a mo to sign his autograph for the blond fan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, you've directed forty-six motion pictures. You host a hit TV show seen around the world. You're the most famous director in the history of the medium... but you're sixty years old. Shouldn't you just quit while you're ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: motionless and quietly devastated as FLASHBULBS CRACKLE o his face. The whiteness transforms into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GLEAMING WHITE TILES of a bathroom. We move past chro fixtures that evoke those in Spellbound and Psycho and ar at that same pudgy hand pouring CHATEAU CHEVAL BLANC '53 a cut crystal glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: soaks in the tub. The champagne glass beside him, his corpulent frame is covered only by the London Times he's reading. Even in this deeply vulnerable state, he maintai the air of a haughty mischievous emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of a bedroom bureau being opened, Hitch's ey shift to the FULL-LENGTH MIRROR on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We catch fleeting glimpses of Alma in a white half-slip a matching bra. She takes out some NYLONS and holds them up the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock watches enthralled. He puts down his glass and shifts a little in the tub, causing the water to lap agai the sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma pauses when she hears the small splashes. Neither up nor amused she continues about her business, taking a ski from the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muhammad had the eyes of peeping Toms gouged out with arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock clears his throat, rattling his paper as if he' been reading the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking of arrows, did you read Mr. Weiler's review in the New York Times? Apparently, he found "the climax" to be -- and I quote -- "overdrawn."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt whether Mr. Weiler has had a climax in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma steps into her skirt as Hitch opens the London Times

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how about this little grenade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North by Northwest reminds us of Hitchcock's earlier, more youthfully inventive spy thrillers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just to drive the nail into the coffin, there's a handy accompanying guide to the new masters of suspense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock zeroes in on the photographs. They're all young Thinner. And with hair.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do they keep looking for new masters of suspense when they still have the original?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be maudlin, you know how much it aggravates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches his reflection in the mirror again and sinks further down into the water to hide his protruding belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma comes in, takes the newspapers from him and puts the the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop reading them. You've been reading them for a week now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts down the TOILET SEAT and sits on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, dear. Am I really too old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A true relic. And lest we forget, a notably corpulent one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes over and kisses the top of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always know precisely where to plunge the dagger, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right between the shoulder blades. I learned it from your pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves off to the mirror to apply lipstick and Hitchco surreptitiously picks up the papers again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seeing Whit for brunch after I drop you off at the studio. Why don't you join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've just established that I'm too corpulent to be seen in broad daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll feel better as soon as you find a project. Hasn't Peggy unearthed any decent books yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleeping pills with dust jackets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma steps back to inspect herself in the full-length mir Today's outfit is, we sense, rather more stylish than wha she would ordinarily wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's gaze never leaves the photo gallery of his younge rivals in the `New Masters of Suspense' article...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very presentable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she elegantly masks her hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, darling. You're pruning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. Hitch grumbles and tosses his paper aside. He rises from the depths but suddenly loses his balance and grabs onto the SHOWER CURTAIN, wrenching it from the META RINGS on the rod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GOD'S EYE view, looking down, as Hitchcock stares up at metal rings SPINNING NOISILY on the metal rod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAMOUS MOUNTAIN TOP icon looms large. TWO GUARDS snap for the arrival of Hollywood royalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock. Mrs. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma waves from the wheel of a GLEAMING BLACK 1957 CADILL Hitchcock sits next to her. He has his two SEALYHAM TERRI on his lap. He nods, awaiting more.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GUARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the dogs) Sirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cadillac pulls up. Alma notes Hitchcock's look of frustrated envy as CREW MEMBERS bustle in and out of STAG 15. It's a hive of activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a story out there waiting for you somewhere, Hitch. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a good-bye peck and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma hands him a compact Fortnum & Mason basket and p on his girth. He opens it to discover CELERY AND CARROT STICKS wrapped in Saran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luxurious, wood-paneled and very British. Hitch sits restlessly behind his desk, receiving his morning shave f his private barber, SILVIO. His longtime assistant, PEGGY ROBERTSON, 40s, crisp, British, fiercely protective of he boss, is going through a list of potential projects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox is offering you The Diary of Anne Frank for the third time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch directs his response to Silvio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience would spend the entire picture waiting for Miss Frank to discover the corpse I'd hidden in the attic. Wouldn't you agree, Silvio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch reaches for a carrot stick and CRUNCHES it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MGM wants you for the Ian Fleming book, Casino Royale, with Cary Grant. Definitely your style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again, turning to Silvio) Doesn't she know I just made that movie? It's called North by Northwest. And "style" is merely self-plagiarism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silvio nods, then recommences the shave.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm treading water, Peggy. I need something fresh. Something different. Without expensive stars like Cary Grant or Miss Kim Novak to pretty it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silvio unintentionally nicks Hitch's face.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A nice, clean, nasty little piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silvio hurriedly dabs away a speck of BLOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch motions for the barber to hold up the mirror. The i of his face overflows the small frame. Repulsed, he leans back his head and makes a hand motion for Silvio to SLIT THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma lunches with screenwriter-novelist WHITFIELD COOK. "WHIT," 50s, is Hitchcock's physical opposite -- dashing, razor-sharp and sophisticated. In fact he'd be at home in of his movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Thank God I had a pocketful of pretzels. I was hiding in that props cupboard all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll teach me to use a bedroom set instead of the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serves you right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh uproariously, quite at ease with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch always said your private life was in danger of being more entertaining than any of your plots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours Alma another glass of wine, not remotely insulte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe he let me have you all to myself for a whole afternoon. Especially looking this beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clinks her glass.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: TrГЁs chic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma turns to look at the menu again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this relentless sycophancy is giving me indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs, his eyes straying to a PRETTY WAITRESS passing Alma notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth? (his eyes return to Alma) Over the moon since I promised her the dedication in my new novel. So what are you working on these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch is going out of his mind looking for his next project. You know how unbearable he is when he doesn't have something lined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost as unbearable as when he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant you. What are you working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm satisfied spending time in my garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is one lucky garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit brings out a set of galleys and slides them across t tablecloth to her.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, I was hoping you might be able to apply your considerable pruning skills to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down and reads the cover page. "Taxi to Dubrovn By Whitfield Cook."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. All is finally revealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches her hand, affectionately. She brushes it away, affectionately...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most fun I ever had was working with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks through the opening pages... taking her time... enjoying making him wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I could give it a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock peeks avidly through the blinds at a smartly dressed KIM NOVAK-TYPE WOMAN hurrying along to some appointment or assignation... Hitch cranes to see who she meeting, but she moves tantalizingly out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch turns back with a sigh towards his desk, covered wi discarded newspaper clippings and boring story proposals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps them off his desk into the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHADOW looms over Peggy at her desk as she sifts throug another round of story ideas. It's Hitchcock. He startles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything. Anything at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts sifting through her tray. She notices the glass his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing suitable. Is that water or do I need to call Alma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drains it playfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin. Mother's ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But something's caught his eye. A circled review of Antho Boucher's column "CRIMINAL MINDS" in the New York Times Review of Books. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boucher says this "Psycho" book by Robert Bloch is `fiendishly entertaining'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds ghastly. Everyone in town's already passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story department finished the coverage this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the one based on Ed Gein, the serial killer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the coverage and reads for himself.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Graphic elements of brutal violence, voyeurism, transvestitism and incest." Certainly not your average run of the mill nutcase, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a grunt of approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy. This is the boy who dug up his own mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely engrossed as he sits reading "Psycho" in a cha by the fire of his elegant Bel Air home. He takes another gulp of wine when he hears Alma enter and slides the wine glass out of view. Alma pops her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Famished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears to take off her coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: If you're good, maybe you can have a grapefruit later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes back in again carrying some galleys, notices th title of Hitch's book -- some trash called "Psycho."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit gave me the galleys of his new book yesterday at lunch. I've already got some ideas on how you could adapt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's elegant, sophisticated, full of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book or Mr. Whitfield Cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She taps Hitch's book dismissively with the galleys of "T to Dubrovnik."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This might be the one, Alfred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it on the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leaves she points to Hitch's `hidden' wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are calories in that, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hitch ignores her and turns to look out the window, h imagination starting to turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed enters the bedroom. His mother, Augusta, is in the bed faced away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you cold, ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. We follow him to the dresser where he lingers a little too long over his mother's open underwea drawer before grabbing the blue coverlet on the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes over and spreads the extra blanket over her. Sti wearing his jacket, he takes off his shoes, gets into bed crawls up next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid, ma... I'm here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he puts his arm around her and pulls her close, we rev his mother's ghoulishly embalmed face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slant of moonlight finds Alma fast asleep until a FINGE nudges her awake. She lifts her satin sleep mask to see Hitchcock holding out his copy of "Psycho."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look of obsession on his face is unmistakable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the bit in the motel bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He switches on the light by her bedside. She sits up, put her glasses and reads from the opened page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mary started to scream, and then the curtains parted further and a hand appeared, holding a butcher's knife. It was the knife that, a moment later, cut off her scream... and her head." (handing him back the book) Charming. Doris Day should do it as a musical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him back the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nothing but low-budget horror movie claptrap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns off the light again and goes back to bed. A dee voice sounds from the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if someone really good made a horror movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hitchcocks eat breakfast on the terrace watching the GARDENERS trim the bushes and rake leaves from the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think of the shock value. Killing off your leading lady halfway through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma can feel Hitch looking at her, waiting for a respons Clearly he isn't going to let this one go.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're intrigued. Admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She butters her toast, casually taunts him by adding a la spoon of marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I think it's a huge mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch falls silent, a chastised schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't wait till halfway through... Kill her off after 30 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch enters with purpose, carrying a stack of photos and articles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, I want you to summon your minions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minions. Certainly. And who might they be...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch heads for his office, in no mood for wise cracks. H spreads out the articles on the desk. Photos and magazine articles about Ed Gein...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them started buying copies of "Psycho."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands in the doorway, watching --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them. I want every copy, nationwide.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have them scour every book shop and library. "Psycho" is my next picture, and I don't want anyone to find out the ending until they see it in the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that celery's affecting your brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks over, notices the LIFE MAGAZINE headline : "HOU OF HORRORS STUNS NATION." Stark black and white photograp expose the nightmarish decay of the Gein house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this? This is so unlike you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly the point, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy watches uneasily as Hitchcock pores over the articl with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PIANIST plays a polite version of Al Jolson's "My Mammy CLOSE ON A MANILA ENVELOPE clutched in one hand behind HITCHCOCK'S back as we follow him travel through the part The clink of champagne glasses as we reveal the GUESTS sa HELLO as he passes...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: And when the Wisconsin Police department raided his farmhouse in Plainview...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is now in position in front of the fire place. Around the coffee table are INVITED GOSSIP COLUMNISTS, including a H HOPPER-TYPE. They take in the gory LIFE MAGAZINE article.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: ..they opened the door only to discover - voila...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces the manila envelope from behind his back and empties THE HORRIFICALLY GORY CRIME SCENE PHOTOGRAPHS ins onto the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... Ten female heads with the tops sawn off, a dozen masks of human skin, and a pair of lips on a drawstring for a window shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch looks down sweetly at the circle of quietly horrifi expressions...

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER TYPE
dialogues.text: Is this really going to be you're next picture, Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is my intention, madam. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch taps the photo of ED GEIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only wish he looked more like William Holden and less like Elmer Fudd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other columnists scribble down the quote.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA HOPPER TYPE
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who finds this offensive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping everyone would. I mean life is deeply offensive and disgusting, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch glides off without missing a beat, past the Servers arriving with more hors d'oeuvres from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try the finger sandwiches -- they're real fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snags a martini and collars Peggy while he's at it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peggy. I'm going to need some research detailing a typical unmarried 30-year-old secretary from Phoenix, Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at the pantry, where Alma can be glimpsed through the swinging door, putting food onto trays.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her monthly rent, what she wears, what she reads, which scent or perfume she prefers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sees WHIT lean into view and innocently whisper something into Alma's ear making her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How she deals with a demanding boss when she's trying to relax on her weekends off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock doesn't notice the joke. He now only has eyes o the pantry ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forges on through the guests only to get waylaid by Le It is a classic Hitchcock moment, a character needing to someplace being held up by someone who wants to chat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the faces of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Hitch. This thing's strictly for the drive-in crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch smiles tightly and extricates himself, heading on t the kitchen through more annoying guests --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit leans against the stove watching Alma expertly arran the next round of hors d'oeuvres coming in from the kitch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if this were a Hitchcock picture what would two characters like us, married to other people, be saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to pretend you're not upset he hasn't read it yet, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a big boy. I can take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I loved it. What terrific fun it must have been to research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly more fun than reading those reviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he really will read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, over Whitfield's shoulder, Alma sees Hitch loom in the doorway. Whit notes the tiny change in her eyes an turns.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch stares blankly at him while Alma turns and busies herself over the sink, hiding an almost imperceptible blu

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to admit, Hitch, I ran all over town looking for a copy of "Psycho" but couldn't find a single one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how that could have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sips his martini, a picture of innocence. Then lean to Whit's ear and whispers - just like Whit leaned into Alma's ear a moment earlier.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't stop looking on my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy appears in the pass-through, beckoning Hitch to hur back into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch returns to see the other GUESTS are now passing aro the GEIN PHOTOS. They look utterly confused and horrified a couple of them are even gathering their coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing together watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen happier faces on a school bus going over a cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you it would be too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they can't stop looking, can they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slurps his martini, sharing a smile with Lew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paramount President BARNEY BALABAN, 70s, ferocious, righteous, sits behind his impressive desk flanked by two CONSERVATIVELY-ATTIRED EXECUTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock and Wasserman sit across from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audiences want to be shocked, Barney. They want something different. And this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to the untouched copy of "Psycho" in front of Balaban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, Hitch, every time you want to do something "different" like The Wrong Man or Vertigo, someone loses money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock stares unblinking, giving nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we should stop trying to give them something new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe Paramount one last picture, Hitch. Can't you do something like North by Northwest but for us this time instead of for MGM?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's stare remains inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've offered you dozens of perfectly good properties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Psycho."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasserman gives Balaban the same glacial stare. The Param executives shift uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one respects the name Hitchcock more than Paramount. But even a talented man sometimes backs the wrong horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you telling me "no?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban maintains a calm, pleasant front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know me better than that, Hitch. I would never say "no" to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's suppressed rage is building...but Balaban says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Lew walk down the stairs and through the leafy courtyard past Hitch's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a putz. You know what his family did before they built those movie palaces? Ran a grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father ran a grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. That's what I'm saying. He should show some respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch turns to Lew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think I've lost my touch, Lew. My association with television has cheapened me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you referring to that deal I got you where Bristol-Meyers pays you twenty-nine grand an episode and you own the negative? That's my kind of cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just want the same thing over and over. They've put me in a coffin and now they're nailing down the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew puts a comforting hand on him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, I will never let that happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch doesn't respond, Lew sensing the true depth of his friend's melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much do you think you can make this picture for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred thousand... Give or take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew digests the figure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have whisky in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA does afternoon laps in the pool. A contemplative Hitchcock wanders down to the pool side wearing black sunglasses and a business suit. He watches Alma a moment. Finally she notices him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, then sits at the table to pour himself a glass lemonade. Alma gets out and towels herself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed you didn't give Whit's book a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows you well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down next to him, noticing a tiny hole in her swimsuit. It's starting to look a little threadbare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy the pool now. We might not have it for that much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks off cryptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paramount refuses to finance the movie. Imagine -- The studio that brought you Martin and Lewis and The Greatest Show On Earth considers Psycho distasteful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes some fallen leaves off his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lew can't find the money. Not quickly enough at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't reply. She knows him well enough too and doesn question him further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to go it alone, old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll finance the movie ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to have to sell the entire house or just the pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Hitch but he's not joking. She turns to surv their beloved home and gardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me and I won't ever ask again. Why this one, Hitch? It's not just because so many people are telling you 'no,' is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without turning he takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the fun we had when we started out and there was so little money and time? We took risks, we experimented. We invented new ways of making pictures because we had to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment as he gazes across the pool.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to feel that kind of freedom again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look into her eyes for the first time. A glim of the real Hitchcock. Someone even his wife doesn't see often...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The famous gates and the executive building beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Barney, we're about to propose a restructured deal for "Psycho"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban watches Hitchcock and Lew closely. Hitchcock agai like a waxworks Buddha, revealing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finance it. Independently. Paramount only distributes it...in exchange for 40 percent of the profits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. But tell us, what exactly is Paramount distributing? Is this still a picture about a queer killing people in his mother's dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What this picture is about is the reputation of Alfred Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one's arguing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney, it's very simple. This is Mr. Hitchcock's next film. Are you in or are you out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, obviously you have a lot of passion for this project. Let me talk it over with a few people internally and I'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban takes in their inscrutable stares. Not unimpresse their chutzpah, he leans back and puts his hands behind h head, a king in his counting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. We'll take that deal. If you can get the money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Hitchcock speaks up :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already got it, Barney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out his PERSONAL CHECKBOOK and opens it on the d Barney watches as Hitch takes the onyx fountain pen from mount.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who do I make it out to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Alma lie side by side in their separate beds. A copy of "The Dance of Death" by Strindberg lies on Hitch' bedside table. All traces of his bravado are gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this picture fails, Alma, we'll be in for a long, humiliating bout of crow- eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie will be splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the movie? Not in the least. But of you? Unquestionably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUDGY FINGERS part the slats of the blind. Hitch stares o hoping for some human moment to spy on. He's restless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy ushers JOSEPH STEFANO, 30s, into Hitch's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Stefano. Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock leaves Stefano's hand dangling in mid air and s down at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH STEFANO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry I was late. My shrink session ran overtime. I see him every day and it's still not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought only director's assistants needed psychiatrists, not writers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stefano laughs off the barb and takes a seat as Peggy sli out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stare at each other but Stefano's not remotel intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see a shrink, Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's eyes follow a plume of cigar smoke curling up to ceiling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gaze remains pointedly fixed on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must say it boggles the mind to imagine what you and your "shrink" could possibly talk about daily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual: sex. Rage. My mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock lowers his gaze, suddenly intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits with the Hitchcocks' ACCOUNTANT who's consultin ledger. She sits at her desk in the corner of the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still the federal income tax payments... the property taxes... Not to mention the absence of any salary while he's actually making the film...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop waffling, Donald. Give it to me straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Accountant takes off his glasses, plucking up the cou to look his favorite client in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch wasn't exaggerating. If the film's a flop, you're going to have to sell the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma digests this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you suggest we cut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's moved to the kitchen table and is sorting through accounts herself, the dogs at her feet. Her face is now properly filled with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch enters, holding out some typed pages. Alma covers h worry. He puts the pages on the table next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got Joe Stefano to write out the first few scenes. Why don't you take a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes Stefano's pages and starts to read...Hitch goe the fridge and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're about to have dinner. You don't need anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door. Leans against the fridge door. Hitch w but she gives nothing away...until she off-handedly place the pages on the table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a blank page being fed into a Corona typewriter. FINGERS pound out "PSYCHO"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Hitchs step outside. The Cadillac is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma follows him out and makes a final adjustment to his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing worse than a visit to the dentist is one to the censor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, Alfred, don't lose your temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intimidating plaque for the MPAA's "PRODUCTION CODE ADMINISTRATION OFFICE" on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stefano's TITLE PAGE is tapped angrily by GEOFFREY SHURLO 70s, the much-feared administrator for the Motion Picture Production Code. He sits at the head of a big table with ASSISTANTS. Sitting opposite are Hitchcock, Peggy and sev silent PARAMOUNT EXECUTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Code will absolutely not permit you to show a knife penetrating a woman's flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you, Geoffrey, my murders, are always models of taste and discretion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any improper suggestion of nudity in this murder scene in the shower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't be nude. She'll be wearing a shower cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock makes a note. A man utterly devoid of any sense humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might accept a shot from outside the bathroom window with Marion in silhouette above the shoulders -- provided the glass is frosted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch greets the suggestion with barely concealed contemp Shurlock turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: G EOFFREY SHURLOCK
dialogues.text: Then -- this scene with the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's completely necessary. Marion flushes evidence later found by her sister. It's a clue to the girl's disappearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No American movie has ever found it "necessary" to show a toilet, let alone to flush it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch turns to Peggy and a Paramount Executive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we ought to shoot the film in France and use a bidet instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response from Shurlock's end of the room. Peggy stares down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, if this office denies you a seal, and we're certainly heading in that direction, your movie will not be released in a single theater in this country. Will you be making jokes then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock gives a slow but meaningful shrug.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY SHURLOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. Now why don't we go all the way back to page two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: boiling with rage as we hear the flurry of script pages -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight filters through sheer curtains revealing Hitchco trying his best to recline on an ANALYST'S COUCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in Hollywood resents me. I make them millions... and yet every year I sit at those dreadful award show dinners, waiting for them to say, just once, "You're good."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the luxurious office.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They take sadistic pleasure in denying me that one little moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch fumbles for a handkerchief and mops his brow.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll have to excuse me, doctor. I'm not used to this... process...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Hitch claws at his tie. It's hot in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, more and more lately, I've been having these... impulses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The analyst's MONTBLANC pen makes a note on a pad. We not that his hands are surprisingly coarse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of impulses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Hitchcock is still. He stares up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strong ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRIDGE DOOR SNAPS OPEN to reveal Hitchcock's FACE in th darkness. He's in his pajamas. His hand trembles next to stack of chicken breasts and moves to an upturned GRAPEFR HALF at the back of the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls it out it to reveal a hidden stash of foie gras under the hollowed out grapefruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's about to devour it when he catches sight of his DISTORTED REFLECTION in the chrome shelving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs away, disgusted at this monster before him, the light of the fridge illuminating his expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door is quietly shut and locked. The bottom drawer of a filing cabinet is inched open. A hand rummages deep insid and teases out a bulging MANILA FOLDER. A hidden stash of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DESK LIGHT is switched on revealing HITCH. He careful extracts the contents of the folder and lays them onto th desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A personal collection lovingly kept. He settles in to stu it, picking out his favorites, arranging them in order. They're all in the same pose, all with hair pinned up int perfect bun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at each image with intensifying desire. He's cre all of them. Every detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's no longer enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of HANDSOME ACTOR HEADSHOTS on a table. HITCH glare the waiting ACTORS in the hallway through the blinds. He turns back to Peggy and Alma and pulls a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send them all back to Glendale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch returns to the table to ponder yet more headshots. Peggy shares a glance with Alma, then slides over RODDY MCDOWELL'S HEADSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lazar Office tells me he's crazy to work with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell "Swifty" he shouldn't have overexposed his client on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike certain people we could mention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch ignores the barb. Undeterred, Alma pushes her ace c a photo of ANTHONY PERKINS, radiating offbeat sensitivity teen idol looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the duality he could bring to Norman. The rage lurking behind that little-boy-lost grin. The winsome charm he uses to keep from being found out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Alma, you're not suggesting that Mr. Perkins is -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She raises her pinky finger just slightly. Alma nods with judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pondering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony Perkins now sits across from Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't count how many times I've seen Strangers On a Train and Rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Norman is the logical extension of the boys in those movies. Appealing, sensitive, suffering the terrible burden of being forced to pretend to be something he is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock's deeply-felt remark lands with Perkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My only worry is that playing Norman might cut too close to home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's calmness is strangely reassuring to the young actor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was incredibly close to my mother. So close I remember wishing my father would drop dead. And then when I was five, he did just that...He keeled over from a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see I've been guilty my whole life, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch is enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to remember this is all just make believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perkins wishes he could be more reassured...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to be prudish, but how far do you plan to push Norman's relationship with his mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further than you can possibly imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Perkins uncertain expression -- what is he letting him in for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock's RED SWEATING FACE as he grunts and heaves. He dressed in gardening gear, laboring in the full bloom of rose garden. Alma pushes a WHEELBARROW filled with manure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shovels the manure around the rosebushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting blisters just looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop grumbling. A bit of fresh air and exercise is exactly what you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds his PRUNING SHEARS menacingly over a deep red Sydonie rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could get Grace Kelly to play the girl, they'd let me get away with anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you can't. She's a princess now which makes her permanently unattainable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock beheads the ROSE, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all the more desirable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His shears are now poised over a yellow specimen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew suggested Deborah Kerr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too... Scottish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock cuts it too and moves on to the stem of a perfe pink rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Janet Leigh? She's always the `good girl' but she did awfully well in Touch of Evil. Lew mentioned her name. Do you remember how you always remarked on her figure at the Wassermans' parties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the shears hover on the stem, unsure whether to cut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SLENDER WAIST AND AMPLE BOSOM OF JANET LEIGH as she elegantly enters the dining room of Chasen's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch stands to greet her, his eyes follow her across the room in some private rapture..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma watches as Janet removes her glove and shakes Hitch' hand...before he guides her to the spot to his left, acro from Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch finishes telling his story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course the real secret of Mrs. Simpson's appeal to the Duke of Windsor was that she could make a toothpick feel like a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so deadpan... it takes a moment before she laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've been so immersed in preparing to play Marion I'd almost forgotten how to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch summons the waiter with a snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you must try the banana shortcake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing for me, thank you. I'm watching my figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma watches all this with a fixed smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the only one. (to the waiter) We're fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock ignores Alma, gesturing to the waiter again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring her the banana shortcake, George. In fact make it two large portions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pointedly shifts to face Janet.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So do tell me, how else have you've prepared to play Marion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've written a complete history for her...It seems silly, but it helps me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to pull a LEATHER NOTEBOOK from her handbag,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's gaze locks onto her silken blonde hair, tied immaculately into the classic `Hitchcock bun'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound silly at all. Tell me one of her deepest secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quick look to Alma, as if to ask for permission before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads a double life. For instance, when she works at the Lowery office, she wears Tweed perfume. But, when she and Sam are together, she recklessly breaks out her one expensive bottle -- "My Sin" by Lanvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices Alma's expression.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But...I do have a concern or two. I'm an actress but I'm also a wife and mother first, so I'm wondering just how you'll do that shower scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and the Shurlock Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just... I mean even if you shoot me from here -- (she indicates a spot just above her bosom) -- well it's not as if my figure is boyish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock looks down at her torso, as if noting it for th first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to put your mind at rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma reacts as Hitch reaches over and gives Janet's hand reassuring squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I show you some of Mr. Saul Bass's marvellous story boards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch pulls out his folio case and shows Janet the storyboards (which we don't see).

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I plan to shoot quick bits of film from various angles.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut together, this montage will suggest nudity and violence but nothing will actually be shown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet studies them, deeply impressed. And relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And having you in the shower will make it all the more tit-illating --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's had enough. Janet's smile falters as she watches A get up and head to the restroom. She's unsure of what jus happened but Hitch carries on regardless, either entirely oblivious or not caring at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma enters and looks in the mirror, quietly devastated. looks up to find another reflection in a mirror behind he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma is SUDDENLY TRANSFORMED into a Technicolor Hitchcock blonde. In a beautiful Edith Head gown, her skin is velve perfection, her hair blonde and impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come off it, old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bitchy STUDIO HEAD'S WIFE snaps Alma out of her reverie joining her at the sink to powder her face.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO HEAD WIFE
dialogues.text: Alma, dear, how lovely to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO HEAD WIFE
dialogues.text: You're looking a little pale. No wonder with that thing your husband's working on now. You can't possibly approve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had a drink too many but the throwaway comment stil hits Alma hard.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO HEAD WIFE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you letting him do something so tasteless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't upset yourself, darling. It's only a bloody movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like in a Douglas Sirk movie. The same roses that are the `color' of Janet Leigh. Alma hovers with her secateurs fo moment and then starts SNIPPING off their heads with a Caligula-like lack of mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vase of flowers, none of them pink, in the center of th table. Hitch STARES into a refrigerator filled with borin tasteless health-conscious food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma enters briskly and holds up a handwritten LIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made a list of places where we can tighten our belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She places the list on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't hurt for us all to learn the art of self restraint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch goes over and picks it up, and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gardeners only once a week and weekends off for the driver? No. Absolutely not. We'll find other places to cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any other places. And furthermore, they'll be no more shipments from Maxim's either. We can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snatches the list out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foie gras at Chasen's is more than adequate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But those geese are from Barstow not Marseilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have to make our little sacrifices for the greater good, don't we, Alfred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves Hitch to resume contemplating the contents of fridge...but there's nothing there to satisfy his growlin hunger. He SLAMS the fridge and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we're moving through an empty living room, prowl just like in a Hitchcock movie as we hear CLUNKING, then over to catch a glimpse of Ed as he drags A WOMAN'S BODY, feet-first up the stairs. The clunking is from her head o the steps, which is wrapped in her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed approaches the shower curtain, then yanks it open with METALLIC SCREECH. He pushes the body into the tub. Pulls dress off her head and drops it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here. I'm going to get the knives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan to REVEAL HITCHCOCK standing in the corner. He loo terrified but completely enthralled -- he can't resist creeping forward for a thorough inspection. Hitch's POV a steps closer to the tub and glimpses the woman's blood- spattered WHITE BRA and GIRDLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly -- FINGERS CLUTCH the rim of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch recoils but she LURCHES UP and GRABS his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed! Ed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock bolts upright in bed, face beaded with sweat in moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment to get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Am I making a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma stirs in her bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if it's another Vertigo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up. Just get the first take under your belt you'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hitch isn't looking convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign posted outside the soundstage reads, "PRODUCTION REHEARSALS 9401. ABSOLUTELY NO VISITORS!" It only makes passing REPORTERS AND WORKERS more curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, it's a hive of quiet purposeful activity. A.D. HI GREEN escorts VERA MILES across the far side of the stage She's 30, a classic blonde porcelain beauty in the Grace Kelly mold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still can't believe you cast Vera Miles as the sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sits in his director's chair reading a copy of the London Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've still got her under contract. I may as well get something out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather a thankless role, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an utterly thankless girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he still watches VERA over the top of his newspaper a the A.D. leads her through the maze of hazardous cables a light stands towards the fitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes an actor in a HIGHWAY PATROLMAN'S UNIFORM tryi on various sunglasses with the prop master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock's office called again. They want to know when you'll be making the changes to the script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch gets up from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more we frustrate them the more their interest will wane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes over to specify the correct sunglasses that shoul worn. The Cop puts on the MIRRORED shades. Hitch nods his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A RAIL OF SWIMSUITS. Alma browses through them carefully. They are all perfectly nice, if a little staid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes suddenly catch a COLORFUL SWIMSUIT on the end of rail. It's striking, even a little risque. She looks at t price tag. It's insanely expensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to go... stops... then impulsively turns back a grabs it, heading into the changing room and closing the behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: light blasts through A TINY HOLE in the wall. An EYE positions itself in front of the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the VOICES of two women quietly conversing on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strains to get a better view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We catch teasing glimpses of golden girl Vera Miles strip down to bra and panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCHCOCK'S EYEBALL fills the frame as he peers through t tiny hole. We reveal Vera with sharp, bohemian costumer R RIGGS, 27, who drapes taupe-colored fabric to Vera's contours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it to me gently. Am I playing a lesbian librarian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the fabric) He chose it himself and had it imported from Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera laughs dryly at a WIG on a dummy head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I wear that, I'm going to look like George Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait until you see the undergarments he picked out for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera tosses off her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to keep telling myself, one more picture and I'm free as a bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unhooks her bra and crosses to hang it on a hook righ near the HOLE where we just saw Hitchcock's eye. His eye gone, only darkness from the other side. Vera feels a chi and instinctively covers her breasts with her arm.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there a fan blowing somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita returns with a punitive bra and girdle.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. The old man really is unhappy with me, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch knocks at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you decent my dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANET steps out dressed in a crisp, sexy white shirt and pencil skirt. She does a twirl for him. The effect is stunning. Even the stagehands stop to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His picks a tiny piece of lint on her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he escorts her onto the soundstage, Tony comes up to g them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you again for this opportunity, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just "Hitch", Tony. Hold the cock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet caught that -- she's clearly amused. Tony gives her gracious peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at you two. America's favorite boy and girl nextdoor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet flicks a glance back at Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're about to move to a whole new neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already, Tony can't help feel a little excluded from Hitc and Janet's little clique. Hitch ushers them across the soundstage where the crew are assembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Janet. Morning Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera Miles marches up in her frumpy tweed suit and wig.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Thanks" for the wardrobe, Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already moving past her) That's hand-woven imported camel hair from Rodier. Don't you approve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checkmates him with a ravishing smile.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One thing, though. My script is missing the last ten pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's is. Until Alma finishes the revisions. Now hurry along, Vera. You're just in time for the oath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steers her towards a line of laughing CREW MEMBERS for a circle with the rest of the cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Janet by the hand, placing her right next to him officiously raises his right hand. The cast and crew duly follow suit, all except for Vera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I solemnly promise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I solemnly promise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Vera's sarcasm) That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I will not divulge the plot nor the many secrets of Psycho...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tilt up to Janet's look of mock disapproval. Vera po her tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To friends, relatives, trade reporters or columnists -- not even to outgoing President Dwight D. Eisenhower, God bless him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone cracks up, but Hitchcock's only interested in th reaction of his new blonde, standing in pride of place, r beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA sits at the desk typing away at the revisions for "Psycho." -- we see the title page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny solitary figure with nothing for company but a vas wilting flowers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, takes off her glasses and pushes aside her corrections, suddenly fed up with the all the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out at the swimming pool, sparkling in the sunlight... then turns to the expensive-looking SHOPPING half-open on the side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a LOUD SPLASH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alma plunges into the water wearing her striking new swimsuit. She breaks into a front crawl. Her strokes are vigorous, surprisingly so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drives the length of the pool, her arms slashing thro the water with increasing speed, her feet kicking out wit rising intensity... harder and harder... faster and faste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch guides Janet and Tony across the sound stage to the of Norman's parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Hitch, explain to me why I'm watching Marion undress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I should take offense at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and Tony laugh. Hitch's eyes light up at this display mischief from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...Perhaps as a boy, Norman secretly watched his mother preparing for her nightly bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there was a transom over the bathroom door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- one he could access with a chair so long as he was stealthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a boy's first glimpse of a naked woman is usually his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...I'm reliving the past, repeating a ritual with Marion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the actor. You figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony flinches at Hitch's brusque response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the set wall, where Hitch removes a painti to reveal the PEEPHOLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, I have a question. Why is the hole much larger on this side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the better to see you at the greatest possible angle my dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet simply steps up and presses her face to the hole. H studies her profile, quietly thrilled at her curiosity. T hangs back, watching Hitch watching her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You really do your research, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my Jesuit work ethic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a quick peek through the hole now too...then put the painting carefully back into place over it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: The truth is... I'm only happy when I'm working...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lies on his Analyst's couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and if I'm not working then I'm nothing. I'm not even a person. I'm just a collection of molecules. A useless cylinder of ugly flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Analyst circles one of his notes on a pad with his Montblanc. Again, we notice how rough-hewn his hands are.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What about your mother? Let's go back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch looks over at the unseen analyst and considers him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was an extraordinary person. She exposed me to Ibsen, Strindberg, Shaw. She hoped I would go into engineering -- carry a lunch pail, gold watch at fifty.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: She didn't approve of your career?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To her, movie people were akin to thieves and prostitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to look out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I misbehaved, she'd make me stand at the foot of her bed and discuss how I planned to become a better boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Analyst leans forward and we see his dirty, worn-down fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: ANALYST'S VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Have you ever considered that your deep desire to gain the approval of your industry represents a textbook case of transference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Oscar is your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ED GEIN. In his Sunday best, his shovel leaning agai the mahogany-paneled wall in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fine one to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock leads Janet to a row of brassieres, all laid ou for inspection. They are all white with recognizable labe Berlei, Triumph, Marks & Spencer. He picks out one of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be wearing a white bra like this for the opening scene on the bed. And then after you've stolen the money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move on to a second row of brassieres - all dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I switch to one of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, correct. She moves over to a mannequin displayin the iconic jet black brassiere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don't want to look at something a little more elegant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They have to look like they were bought at Sears and Roebuck. I want every woman in the audience to look up at Janet having sex with John Gavin and think, `that could be me'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet reads the label. It's "Maidenform."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the brand I wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch digests the information and turns to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready for a fitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
