dialogues.text: As Rita starts to measure Janet's chest, Hitchcock lifts hands and `frames' her...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O. PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We travel across the rooftops of downtown Phoenix and finally, through the heat, pick out a certain hotel window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Hitchcock's FRAMING HANDS as they now travel up an open window with blinds half down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go under the blinds and match dissolve into the room itself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCHCOCK'S HANDS have now become THE CAMERA, recording t scene already underway and now watched by HITCHCOCK, his DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY and CREW from across the stage...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We pan over and discover John and Janet on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the camera moves to Janet and John making out on the b It's serious stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She'll be wearing only her undergarments and a large glow of satisfaction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANET smiles up at John contentedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching from his directing chair. Peggy stands next to h

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck getting this one past the censor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma drives the gleaming black Cadillac through the UNIVE GATES and pulls up to the production office outside the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma collects the script pages off the front seat and wal into the production office just missing Whit as he stroll back towards the writers building with a couple of pretty SECRETARIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit pauses when he spots the Hitchcocks' CADILLAC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You girls go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRETTIEST ONE stops to make Whit light her cigarette before catching up with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy reads the final pages while Alma inspects the production boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me, the credits should read "Screenplay by Joseph Stefano and Alma Reville."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people who matter know. That's all that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she makes a few more changes to the schedule. Alma tur to Peggy whose face tightens as she continues reading. Clearly it's strong stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hate to see Shurlock's face when he reads this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the pages down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma, you always know the answer. Is this really going to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A candid moment between the two women... but Alma doesn't answer, just leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma emerges into the sunshine and looks across at the soundstage, wondering whether she should go over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to see Whit leaning against the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been hiding yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing the revisions on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to the PSYCHO HOUSE on the ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is the old boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a state of unbridled ecstacy now that he's back on the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. I've got eight hundred words to do for Reader's Digest on what it's like to be married to a man obsessed by murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a better idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't we drive out to Santa Barbara? We'll have Emilio fry up those juicy steaks we like at El Encanto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He playfully tugs at her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No shoptalk ... No silly magazine articles...just a wonderful meal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's expression gives away nothing as we pan over to th WINDOW of the production office and notice the tell-tale in the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch looks out at Whit and Alma through the window, just like he did with the other couple earlier. Except this li interaction is far from dull.

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: We're ready for you on the set, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hitch doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA enters the silent, empty house smiling to herself. S walks through to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and puts the grocery bags down on the counter. She list The house is eerily quiet, until, from behind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there a line at the market?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma looks up, but doesn't turn round, well used to Hitch cryptic ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Actually, I'm back sooner than I expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on an apron and gets to work, preparing dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a cocktail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads for the liquor cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (he starts to head off) And you shouldn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock stops. Pulls out a CELERY STICK from one of the bags and bites it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those haven't been washed yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was filming all day with John Gavin -- a good-looking chap but, really, plywood is more expressive. His love scene with Janet may be most horrifying thing in the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes another BITE, searching her face for some tell-t sign of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even your friend Whitfield Cook would be better in the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should tell Whit that. He'd be flattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets to work preparing a salad. Hitch studies the bac her tiny, vulnerable neck, the delicate sinews and muscle they rise and flex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch arranges his pillows and settles into bed while Alm finishes getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I was too dismissive about your friend Whitfield's book. Perhaps he and Elizabeth could come over this weekend and he can walk me through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's radar activates but Hitch continues oh-so- nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lovely woman, Elizabeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carefully folds his blanket as if wrapping a murder victim. She's not exactly sure what he's implying but she knows she doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was hoping you could come by the set tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see how my day shapes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns onto her side away from him. Pulls the blankets around her, her eyes still WIDE OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You think you can get away with it but you can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's eyes become HITCHCOCK'S EYES, staring ahead intent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You think they can't tell... but they can. They know. It's all closing in on you. The noose is tightening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues, we pull back and see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet emotes for Hitchcock's CAMERA while "driving" a PAR CAR, being rocked by STAGE HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and other CREW time and mark the takes. ELECTRICIAN AND GAFFERS turn mounted lamps that rake across Janet's worried face like car headlights.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could return the money secretly, but what would be the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his brow, getting more intense...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You, Marion Crane. The prim and proper girl who's always been so tight and respectable. So perfect and untouchable. Well, they know all about your dirty little secret, don't they? Your messy, sticky lunchtime trysts. Yes, your boss Mr. Lowery could even smell the sex on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY THE REAR SCREEN film breaks and a frame burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing because Janet is starting to look a lit uncomfortable -- was that meant to be funny? As technicia yell and hustle, Hitchcock turns to Peggy --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Circle that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Janet gets changed, Vera hangs up her frumpy coat on a rack, looking over a little enviously at Janet's good girl/bad girl underwear hanging nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to him much about your personal life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd keep it that way if I were you. (Off Janet's look) He starts by choosing your hairstyle and clothes and then he wants to choose your friends and decide how many children you should have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet finds this a little hard to believe. Vera leans in, lowering her voice.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That poor, tortured soul Jimmy Stewart played in Vertigo? That's Hitch, only younger, slimmer and better-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may well be true but it doesn't bother Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compared to Orson Welles, he's a sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both turn, sensing something -- and see HITCHCOCK'S DISTINCTIVE SHADOW PROFILE in the hallway. The shadow lingers, then recedes like in a scary ghost story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? He's always watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma comes in from her gardening, and settles on the sofa with a cup of tea, a circled copy of TV Guide next to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On television -- the 1950 Hitchcock classic Stage Fright. The credits come up: "Screenplay by Whitfield Cook, Adaptation by Alma Reville."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma watches, thrilled at the sight of her name and Whit' together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words "DIRECTED BY ALFRED HITCHCOCK" overwhelm the sm screen. Alms puts down her fork, no longer hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA heads back to the kitchen, only to pause at the open door to Hitch's study -- there's something on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's personal collection. Alma enters and starts to go through them. Each photo is turned over a little more rou than the last. It's hard to tell whether she's more angry the photos or the fact that they've been deliberately lef for her to find...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes off an earring, picks up the phone and starts dial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the crew prepares the car set to go again, Hitch strid over to PEGGY who's dialing a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hold up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the phone himself just as Vera Miles emerges fro her dressing room, script in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, I'm stuck on Lila's first scene. I don't know how strongly I should confront Sam and the detective and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fake it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his back on her and dials. The ENGAGED TONE blar in his ear. His eyes narrow at some crew members fussing bits of LIGHT and SOUND EQUIPMENT.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does it really require two men to carry a light stand?

dialogues.speaker: A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it right away, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes off to fix it. Off Peggy's questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different when their pay is coming out of your own pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raps the receiver button, more intensely this time, an redials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Alma's still on the phone to Whit, basking in his cha Her feet are up. There's a drink in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, I think that sounds like a fabulous idea. We'll have a late lunch. I'll make the reservation for one thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till then, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, toying with her earring, feeling better alr when the PHONE rings again very quickly. She picks up wit even thinking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you forget now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pudgy fingers clench the coiled PHONE CORD as we move up Hitch's face. He's silent as a burglar, not even daring t breathe...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Whit? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blood drains from Hitch's face as he very slowly and carefully replaces the receiver. His mind starts to spin. He's got to get out of there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lurches towards the production office, starting to sweat, but his path is blocked by GRIPS laying cables. Th set is suddenly a cacophony of noise and chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PR FLACK appears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, every press outlet is driving us crazy for photos --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch brushes past him to find another route but more gri are moving a ladder. He turns, kicks a platter of healthy snacks out of the way, only for an ARCLIGHT to swivel in face and blind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? You've gone very pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy's face suddenly comes into focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop trailing me like a puppy dog and get me something long, cool and wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the key!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snatches it and pushes past her, leaving her flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCH exits the soundstage doors, only to find the humorl face of BARNEY BALABAN blocking his office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Hitch. How's the picture? I'm hearing interesting things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a wonder you can hear anything over the noise coming from the Shurlock office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban offers up his handkerchief. Hitchcock waves it aw even though he's now covered in sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be in a position of just hearing things, Hitch. It's time you showed me some footage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see if you're making a picture Paramount can actually release.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you well know, Barney, my contract guarantees me final cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your contract also says Paramount isn't required to distribute any film that could cause us embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the last five Martin and Lewis pictures you're all so proud of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the door in Balaban's startled face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock loosens his collar and catches a glimpse of him in a mirror. He's unraveling and it shows.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I demand to see some footage, Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lowers the window blinds over Balaban's face and fumbles for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connect me to Maxim's of Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the key and opens the liquor cabinet ignoring th INSISTENT KNOCKING at the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's Alfred Hitchcock in Hollywood, California, Jean-Claude. I need three pounds of foie gras sent on the next flight out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct. Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours himself five fingers of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A majestic view of the coastline as Whitfield Cook's Crea MERCEDES 190CL, zooms along, top down. Alma wears white- rimmed sunglasses and a head scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whitfield, in true Hitchcock leading man style, has the perfect amount of wind blowing through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those steaks haven't changed at all, have they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so nice not to have to take care of someone, even if it's just for an hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes in the sparkling scenery whipping past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit, where are we going? You still haven't told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a little surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A surprise. How fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit just smiles as he jams the acceleration and the car ROARS off down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch stands in the parking lot tapping his foot impatien near the parked Ford Fairlaine police car used in `PSYCHO Janet watches him, sitting behind the wheel of her VOLKSW BEETLE. After a moment she toots her horn and drives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your driver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been asking myself the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you a ride if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock raises an eyebrow at the tiny car, and then, wi great effort inches his massive frame through the open do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Adolf Hitler sketched the design for this car on Ferdinand Porsche's cocktail napkin in a Berlin beer garden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to see Hitch wedged uncomfortably into his seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only now that I truly appreciate just how diabolical Herr Hitler was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices him eyeing the half-eaten bag of CANDY CORN o the dashboard (the kind Norman Bates enjoys throughout "Psycho".)

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. (letting him in on it) I pinched them from Tony's dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one and chews it curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is what they eat at the drive- ins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the whole bag and sets to work, popping them in after the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you only ate Fauchon chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needs must when the devil drives, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so deadpan but now there's no way to tell if he's jo or not. She puts the car into gear, sensing his despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nesting in the sand. Alma and Whit sit out watching the s The water laps over their toes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind that he uses his obsession to fuel his art. I just don't like it when he uses it against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's like any great artist. Impossible to live with but worth the effort. (he throws a rock into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Gogh wasn't exactly a walk in the park either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know when we started out I was his boss? He didn't even dare ask me out until he'd worked his way up to assistant director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit watches as she picks up some sand, lets it run throu her fingers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of that place over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to a SMALL BEACH HOUSE up the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks nice. Terrific location. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him askance. Is he joking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw Elizabeth. Why on earth didn't she tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting on the Hitchcocks' driveway. The VW pu to a stop in front of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet looks over -- decides to risk it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did happen between you and Vera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to make her star. But she chose the life of a housewife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops chewing. We push in as his features turn reflect

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cast her as the lead in Vertigo. Then two weeks before filming she told me was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screws up the empty bag of candy and looks over at Jan Then, almost like a child --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do they do it? Why do they always betray me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she looks across and sees the lonely abandoned little just sitting there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma enters the beach house cautiously and looks around. is old and falling apart with only a few functional furnishings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just leasing it for the offseason. A place to get away from the wife and kid and write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very Bohemian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might find that room interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma looks. The door is partially open -- she sees the on conspicuously new item of furniture. A double bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit. I hope you haven't got the wrong idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a rakish grin, then pushes the door open fur to reveal the deck beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit on a table facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were serious about helping me adapt my book, I thought it would be the perfect hideaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets this sink in, entranced by the incredible view a the crashing surf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, she steps out onto the deck and up to one of the typewriters. Gives the key an approving TAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch enters the empty house at dusk. The dogs greet him. listens a moment... then walks through to the study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch pours himself a brandy and downs it in one. He goes pour himself a second, when he notices something on the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his collection of PHOTOS by the TELEPHONE. They're a neatly stacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a SINGLE GOLD EARRING on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lies in bed, his thoughts racing as he waits for Al to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the sound of the car comes up the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns onto his side and pulls up the blankets, listeni to the sound of the front door ... and Alma's footsteps d the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quietly slips into the bathroom and shuts the door be turning the light on. He watches her shadow through the s of light at the bottom of door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the bathroom light switches off again Hitch hurriedl closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma emerges in her nightgown and stops at his bedside, peering down on him. She's not completely sure that he's actually awake, but she suspects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch eases himself up and looms over Alma to make sure s is safely asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He silently picks up her HANDBAG and takes it to the wind Using the moonlight he searches its contents. Car keys. Lipstick. Purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the first few pages of a story outline:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pages vibrate in his hand as his gaze lowers to revea the rest of the TITLE PAGE: "STORY TREATMENT BY WHITFIELD COOK & ALMA REVILLE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GLISTENING MOUND OF FOIE GRAS spooned into Hitchcock's mouth straight from the MAXIM'S OF PARIS tin. Hitch stand the glare of the open fridge, a beast feeding in its cave shoving in mouthful after mouthful. It's almost pornograp in its indulgence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEIN steps out of the shadows and puts a comforting hand Hitch's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the civilized CLINK of cutlery against china...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch and Alma sit at the table having lunch. Alma eats a pork chop while Hitch defiantly nibbles at his healthy sa He has a nice big glass of red wine which Alma ignores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I read your finished treatment. "Taxi to -- " Where was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dubrovnik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. Dubrovnik. Care to hear my opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no other way of saying it. It's stillborn. Dead in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma blinks, unable to hide her shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mock compassion) The plot's a muddle. Some of the jokes are awfully like things we already did better hundreds of years ago in The Lady Vanishes. And your villain is weak. But the biggest failure is the relationship between the hero and heroine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a radish and bites into it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you weren't so smitten with your friend Whitfield cook you'd probably see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma is entirely stunned. Hitchcock has delivered the kil blow he intended. He gets up and goes over to the garden door.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Women never really care to face the truth when their hearts are involved, do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he steps out into the garden --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know what really goes on between a man and a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch searches his pockets for his lighter but can't find His annoyance only increases when he notices the SCATTERE LEAVES `contaminating` the surface of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the net and starts scooping them out.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody belt-tightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't get the net into the inflow filter so he gets do on his hands and knees and starts PULLING OUT the leaves his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulls out handful after handful of wet leaves, clawing aw at them like a madman...
