dialogues.text: Stage hands and engineers test a row of HOT WATER TANKS installed on the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOLLOW the sound of rushing water through a PIPE as it snakes across the set floor and passes through a fake wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unleashing a stream of STEAMING HOT WATER. The SET HAND g the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the boss we're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and A.D. Hilton Green exchange a glance as Hitchcoc paces up and down in the corridor, eager to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hold-up? Call time was two hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy nervously knocks on Janet's door and peers inside -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita Riggs is hard at work molding MOLESKIN PATCHES to Janet's nipples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're sure this moleskin will stay put?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither woman looks convinced but they proceed with blind faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better. I'm going to be taking a shower all week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Janet slips on her robe, a MOLESKIN TRIANGLE PLOPS ont the floor. Rita and Janet share a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits at her typewriter while Whit stares off, lookin little uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget what Hitch said. He's just feeling his age. He'll come around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's right. It does need more feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma ponders the problem. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why don't we put some in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets to her feet and starts to pace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we need is a better catalyst. Some innocuous little trigger to release all that underlying desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soothing sound of the ocean gives way to the relentle HISS of SHOWER WATER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet nervously removes her bathrobe and heads toward the MOCK SHOWER STALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand and guides her into position.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I explained earlier, this scene will be made up of many shots from Mr. Bass's boards. A series of looks - actions...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, you're the professional. You'll know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around them, the crew frantically finalize the CAMERA and LIGHT SETUPS. MALE CREW MEMBERS look uncomfortable and excited by the unprecedented sight of a virtually nude mo star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saul Bass comes over with his boards and Hitch and he dis the planned shot a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST A.D. HILTON GREEN
dialogues.text: Tony's stunt double is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. There's our murderess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into frame steps Anthony Perkins' FEMALE STUNT DOUBLE, MA wearing a gingham dress, silver wig and BLACK MAKEUP TO M HER FACE. She wields a large PROP KNIFE and almost blocks view of Janet in the white-tiled stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready for our little bloodbath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother always said, "Have confidence in yourself and you can lick anything."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock takes Janet's hand, and with tremendous sinceri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother used to say the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go for a take. Quiet everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over and over, Margo attacks with the knife and Janet tri deflecting the blows but both women are timid and Janet i clearly guarding her modesty and covering her body.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut. More intensely. Let's go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo's KNIFE comes at Janet uncertainly and every which Naked and exposed, Janet defends against the knife blows they come at her but Margo's still pulling her punches--

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. More angry. You are possessed with unbridled homicidal rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut. Cut camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He charges over to Margo to demonstrate the savage stabbi gesture he demands.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does no one understand what I'm trying to accomplish here? I'm older than anyone on this stage and I'm still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone falls silent, unsure how to respond. Hitchcock H OUT HIS HAND.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo places the knife in Hitchcock's palm.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Props. Bring in more blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEMALE MAKEUP ASSISTANT squirts more CHOCOLATE SYRUP "blood" onto Janet from a PLASTIC BOTTLE OF BOSCO.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Roll camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the scene is marked, we see Hitchcock's anxiety. There NO SOUND except Hitchcock's ragged breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock nods. The camera whirs. Hitchcock hoists the kn into the air with terrifyingly convincing power and malevolence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see in the shower from Hitchcock's POV not Janet but GEOFFREY SHURLOCK. Hitchcock SLASHES the censor a killer that sends him reeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock is replaced by BARNEY BALABAN. Hitchcock stabs h with unleashed fury and hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHIT turns, he's naked and smiling. Hitch plunges the kni into his back, and he drops, revealing ALMA, arms around waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back in the real moment -- JANET LEIGH SCREAMING as gives the `performance' of a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock stops stabbing. His heart pounds. He's soaked w sweat. The only sound is the drip-drip-drip of the shower

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he realizes EVERYONE is staring at him. He straightens tie, attempting to regain some semblance of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Print. We've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita escorts the shaken and exhausted Janet off set, pass Vera who's witnessed the whole thing. She's wearing a bathrobe. Janet gives her a look as if to say `Now I understand.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch shuts his office door and leans back against it. He closes his eyes, nauseated and dizzy. He doesn't even nee open them to know who's there, waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Ed. It's really not a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers towards the water cooler, fumbling for a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed steps forward and pours him some water, pats his shoul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just can't keep this stuff bottled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before Hitch can drink it he crashes to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Perkins to react to the noise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come through the door to see Hitch lying on the floo He looks like he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy rushes forward to help. Perkins just stands and sta as if paralysed in some Freudian nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: starts to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is inside the beach house, and partially drowned out b the sound of the crashing waves. Alma and Whit are on the deck, acting out the scene as they write, too engrossed t notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if Helen and Michael try and get into the cab at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even better, what if they reached for the cab door at exactly the same time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma demonstrates so that their hands touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way, we could start close on the hands... (tracking the movement) ... and then tilt up to the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare into each other's eyes, lips just inches apart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That feels better already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the phone intrudes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With some effort, Whit goes inside and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hullo?... Yes... Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes outside, holding out the receiver for Alma.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy grips the phone, her face full of concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you told me only to call in an emergency, but I'm not sure how else to describe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lies slumped on the floor. A compress over his forehead. His head lolls to one side as he slips in and o of consciousness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disarray on the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN BALSAM watches as SAUL BASS, cameraman JACK RUSSEL and A.D. HILTON GREEN argue about the best way to proceed with the staircase sequence. Hitch is conspicuous by his absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they bicker we find Tony Perkins off to one side, sitt in his Mrs. Bates costume, unable to cope. He puts the wi back on his head. There, that feels better...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balsam's finally had it with all the arguing. He walks of past Peggy who's arriving with the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's official. The inmates are running the asylum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy hands Hilton the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilton. I have Mr. Hitchcock for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a warning look. "Watch out. He's in a terri mood." He waves away her concern. It can't be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there, Hitch. We're still working on it. (looking over at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone misses you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, in bed and sick as a dog, has the script, notes an boards on a bed tray. The phone receiver is pressed to hi ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told Peggy and now I'm going to tell you. You have to get this sequence shot today. What's the hold up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried it ten different ways and it looks terrible. Why don't we use inserts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It has to be a high angle. You'll tip off the big surprise! Just get the process shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still clutching the phone, a little nonplussed. Peggy giv him a look: "What did I tell you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma removes the phone from Hitch's grasp. Touches his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more phone calls. You're burning up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burning up our money. We're two days behind and I'm stuck in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch swings his legs out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the set. We can't afford to lose any more time. Two more days of this and the whole production goes under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakily tries to get to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay in bed. I'll deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hate to take you away from your writing partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him back against the pillows. He's too weak to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the blankets. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crew members sit around eating donuts. Assistant director Hilton Green and cameraman Jack Russell are still arguing over the mechanics of the shot with more crew members joi in. It's near pandemonium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Alma steps in the door, and everything stops. Every member snaps to attention as Alma passes by. It's like th school principal arriving after the substitute teacher ha lost control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop work because of me. I'm only here as one of the two people paying your salaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes a seat in Hitch's DIRECTOR'S chair. As her eye dart around the set, it's clear that she IS TAKING EVERYT IN. Peggy flanks her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One seventy three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storyboards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy hands the boards to Alma. She and Hilton quickly re the boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start with the overhead. We'll cut before the fall. Then we'll put Martin in a chair under the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilton looks at Russell. Perfect. He sets ANTHONY PERKINS his dress into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cameraman) And that lens should be a thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy mouths Alma a silent "THANK YOU" for restoring orde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock lies in bed, tossing and turning, the fever onl making his thoughts darker and more obsessive.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You forgot to look in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch notices the SHADOWY FIGURE standing at the end of h bed.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A man like you... Missing the vital clue like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blearily sits up and sees Gein's impassive rustic face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gein steps over to the bathroom and pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother always said if you're going to do a job, do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock enters the immaculate white and chrome room and inspects it... but nothing seems out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down but again, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch gets down on his hands and knees. He runs his fingertips across the smooth white tiles. They start to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprinkled all over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still think they're just writing together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock's face hardens. His lip trembles.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch gets up, opens the medicine cabinet and takes out a BOTTLE OF BAYER ASPIRIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He empties the tablets into the sink and very carefully, sweeps the SAND into the aspirin bottle. He caps it, slip into his robe pocket and turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma spots the towering figure of Balaban stride onto the stage accompanied by a MAN in a cardigan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees her and bristles, clearly surprised to see her th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes in Balaban's companion, and the viewfinder rou his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know David Kirkpatrick. He's working on Jerry Lewis' next picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. They nod politely -- then stand there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's free to help... (a sly smile) if you need it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Just the bustle of crew members in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're nearly three days behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step towards Hitch's empty chair, but Alma mov to block his path. It may be a small gesture, but it's hi charged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney stares down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma. We both know what kind of film this is. (then, closer) The smart thing to do would be to help Hitch finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for your concern, Barney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves closer to him, holding his gaze, not bending on bit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But on a Hitchcock picture, there is only one director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anger flashes on his face as she faces him down, the entire crew behind her now, holding firm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban, incensed, leaves the stage with Kirkpatrick. Alm steps out into the sunlight not far behind them. As she watches them leave, she lets out a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice calls out to her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hitchcock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to see Janet walking over in Capri pants and a sleeveless top. She's carrying an elegantly wrapped packa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind. I heard Hitch was sick so I got him a little something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Alma the gift. A bag of candy corn tied with a ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's been very considerate with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't always had that from my directors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet, you've been very... professional. It hasn't gone unappreciated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes in Janet's unaffected natural beauty -- and he sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't help but notice the second glances Janet is provoking from passers-by now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's an impossible rival for any woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blares deafeningly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stereo. Alma finds Hitch on the sofa swaddled in a blanket and eating ICE CREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I turn that down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She silences the stereo. Hitch doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be pleased to know order has been restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still doesn't look at her, masticating loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thank you would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still two days behind and sixty thousand over budget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already cancelled the wrap party. That'll save us two thousand right there. And you won't be tempted by any champagne and cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls at the bowl of ice cream. He refuses to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware -- all men are potential murderers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yanks it from his grip.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, what's this about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly pulls the ASPIRIN BOTTLE from his robe pocket, building suspense as he unscrews the lid and pours SAND i a tiny pile on the coffee table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spending a lot of time at the beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the bottle, looking for a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where Whit and I are writing. He's rented a place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly the ideal setting to avoid distractions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's very conducive to creative collaboration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already told you -- that treatment is a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't everyone say the same thing about "Psycho"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for the ASPIRIN BOTTLE to throw it away but H grabs it first --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you and Whit having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd. He's working on something new and needs a little help, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a coincidence. I'm working on something new and I could use a little help too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I've been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you spending all hours of the day and night with some overage, talentless mamma's boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He quivers, livid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am under extraordinary pressures on this picture, the least you can do is give me your full support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full support? We've mortgaged our house. My house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma's eyes flash with unaccustomed hurt and fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I remind you that I have weighed-in on every aspect of this film so far, as I have done on every picture you've done in the last three decades. And the first time you show the film, it will be my notes that you want. I celebrate with you if the reviews are good and I cry for you if they are not. I host your parties and put up with those fantasy romances with your leading ladies. And when you're out promoting this film around the world, I will stand beside or, rather, slightly behind you, smiling endlessly for the press even when I'm ready to drop, being gracious to people who look through me as if I were invisible because all they can see is the grand and glorious "Alfred Hitchcock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock is stunned and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, for the first time in years, I dare to work on something that isn't "an Alfred Hitchcock Production" and I'm met with accusation and criticisms. This work I'm doing with Whit gives me pleasure and purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even though that takes absolutely nothing away from you, please consider this a reminder: I am your wife, Alma Reville, not one of the contract blondes you badger and torment with your oh-so- specific direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and, with great dignity, leaves Hitchcock sitti in the gathering gloom. He's not the only one who can del a killer blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with that same lost expression on his face, only now dark shadow and harsh light alternate across his features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NAKED LIGHT BULB dangles from the ceiling as STAGE HAND prepare the film's climactic scene in the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch watches as VERA reaches out to touch the shoulder o Mrs. Bates. We zoom in on her as she reacts in silent hor her HAND flying up to hit the light bulb, throwing crazy shadows all over the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in on Hitchcock's face as the strobing light brie illuminates the image of -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the foot of his mother's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WIG on a stand. A frumpy woman's outfit on a hangar. Ve sits in front of the mirror and unties her own hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita collects Vera's detested wardrobe to take back to wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vera rubs cold cream into her face to remove her make-up. the mirror, she sees Hitch in the doorway as Rita squeeze past him on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wiping off her make-up with a Kleenex) Hello Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Vera. You always make it look so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it was nothing, Hitch. I just faked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a dazzlingly ambiguous Miss America smile.

dialogues.speaker: VERA MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I guess this is au revoir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch comes and stands behind her chair, gazing at her in mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you stay with me? I would have made you as big a star as Grace Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers the question and the man asking it, sensing something different about him now. She continues wiping o her make-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike Grace Kelly, I can pick up my dry cleaning. I've got a family, Hitch. A home. That will always mean more to me than all of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That blonde woman of mystery you're after? She's a fantasy. She doesn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when I thought I understood you so completely -- understood women....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch gives a very slight bow, touches her on the shoulde then leaves. Vera watches him go, struck by his rare show vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind blows sand off the dunes. Alma sits in the parked ca outside the beach house, contemplating the typed pages on seat next to her. An inkling that they may not be as magi as she had hoped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter. She checks her reflection in the rearview and applies some lipstick, readying herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She collects the pages and heads up the steps to the deck She sees two typewriters and paper, but no sign of Whit. Something doesn't feel right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and in the bedroom, through the window, she see Whitfield Cook making love to a young woman -- it is the pretty SECRETARY from the studio lot. Alma and Whit's eye meet. Whit is horrified at being caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma ducks her head, wheels around in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yanks open the door and gets in. Whit runs half dress from the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma, I thought you were coming later tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you rented this place so we could write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I swear -- this just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struggles to get the key in the ignition. He puts his hand desperately on the car door.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You won't say anything, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I won't tell Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit smiles feebly.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can't all be geniuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma tries to hide what a body blow this is.

dialogues.speaker: WHITFIELD COOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alma -- you're incredibly talented. But, after all... we want him to read the script with an open mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't worry about that, Whit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whit watches, deflated, knowing he's ruined everything, h receding figure swallowed up by flickering white light...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew sits with Barney Balaban and two executives. Lew discreetly checks his watch out of boredom. Shurlock and two Assistants look appalled. Composer BERNARD HERRMANN, 40s, prickly, sits in the back row looking suicidal. He glances back at Hitchcock who stands near the screening r door looking worse, if that could be possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock exits and approaches Hitchcock who's waiting in foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to cut all that nudity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What nudity? It was suggested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I definitely saw that knife jabbing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did no such shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd stake my reputation on it. I'm recommending you cut the shower scene entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock is livid but holds his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go over it frame by frame and set up another screening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Shurlock is already walking away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasserman emerges from the screening room conversing with BALABAN. Hitch searches their expressions for some indica but Balaban strides off without saying a single word to h

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say it was a four-letter review and it wasn't `good'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harsh reality devastates Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Screw him. It's too late for Paramount to back out no matter what Balaban says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The other route is to recut it as a two- parter for the TV series. Because of the budget and the Hitchcock name, we stand a good chance of breaking even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, Hitch doesn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I made Jimmy Stewart a millionaire of Winchester 73 and that was a dog. At least I could sit through your picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch stares bleakly off. He can't help noticing the KIM NOVAK-TYPE he spied on earlier outside, hand in hand and kissing her date.

dialogues.speaker: LEW WASSERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More importantly, what does Alma think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits with the Hitchcocks' ACCOUNTANT going over the books again, looking at the revised figures. They close t books and sit back and look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else we can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. This time he can't bring himself to look her in eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just have to wait and see how the movie turns out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma gets up and crosses to the window. Stares out at the pool reflecting a leaden sky... and the clumps of dead le floating across its surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it is only a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs, GEOFFREY and STANLEY, lap away at a water bowl the study. A splash or two of something is added to the b from above. It's being poured from Hitch's brandy glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pours himself another glass, leaving the dogs lapping hap away as he goes over to the Steinway Grand. There's a ban silver-framed PHOTOS on top. He pauses to take a proper l at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His and Alma's life together in movies. Smiling at Premie with Cary Grant and Grace Kelly. On vacation with Jimmy a Gloria Stewart. At a black tie event with Ingrid Bergman Gregory Peck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's the PHOTOGRAPH tucked away at the back that he w to see most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK AND WHITE PUBLICITY STILL taken on the set of The Mountain Eagle in 1926. He picks it up and looks at it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Hitchcock in front of the camera, dramatically calling "Action!" on his first film. His eyes don't have move far to find ALMA, standing just behind him, making n on her clipboard, the same intense, serious look on her f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look so young...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch turns to look out the window, thoughtful -- Hitch's POV. It's SNOWING outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to discover the window is now in a basement by a single oil lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Gein sitting at his workbench. Hitchcock is perch on a stool nearby watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trash and newspapers are piled everywhere. There is grime dark stains on the cabinets and counters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my favorite place. I just shut the doors and leave the world behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch watches Gein as he threads a needle, stitching something expertly together. He notices there's no hint o tremble in Gein's hands.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pass me that bag, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch passes over the shopping bag... then pulls up his c feeling a chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you get lonely out here sometimes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always talk to my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear CARS pull up -- a lot of them. The sound of ME shouting. Flashing RED AND BLUE LIGHTS. LOUD KNOCKING at

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTSTEPS thunder above him. DOZENS OF OFFICERS are fanni out all over the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SCHOEPHOERSTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch watches as Gein just sits there and the sound of SHOCKED reactions and horrified GASPS continue above...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN SCHOEPHOERSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think we found his hiding spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't go in there. That's my mother's room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAR HEADLIGHTS blast through the window and Hitchcock fin sees the basement room properly for the first time; KNIVE all shapes and sizes...JARS OF PRESERVED BODY PARTS...and SEVERED HANDS, FOLDED IN PRAYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM UPSTAIRS the sound of splintering wood.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They can't go in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my mother's room!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed springs to his feet, screaming it out as he BOLTS UPST and the pandemonium continues (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bleak reality of Gein's lair hits him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more profound and horrible than he could ever have imagined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lush ROMANTIC SCORE starts to SWELL, mercifully drownin all out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titles from a dark 1946 romantic melodrama fill the scree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma sits watching the afternoon movie alone, brushing th dogs on the sofa next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock reads Alma's fragile emotional state and enters sits down beside her and studies the screen for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An odd little movie. Of course, Colbert is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma nods. They watch for a beat longer.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How was the beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold and miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Barney Balaban's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates the over-ripe dialogue coming from the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whit isn't worth a damn when he's not working with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And neither am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma takes in his reflective expression, but says nothing

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't pull off the picture this time. It just sits there, refusing to come to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no other way to say it... It's stillborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALMA turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sits there bereft in the lonely silence.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I let you down, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves closer and takes her hand. Gives it a small sque

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You deserved better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still doesn't move. After a moment Hitch gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll go and feed Geoffrey and Stanley, shall I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits with the dogs padding after him. She turns back the screen and more of that stilted, mannered dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon. The ONLY LIGHT from inside the house is the in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We glimpse the figure in the window. A corpulent man in profile, like a Hopper painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sits in his nightgown, pushing some VEGETABLES arou his plate -- his healthy midnight snack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma enters in her robe. Hitch watches her. She goes to t fridge, opens the PRODUCE DRAWER and from under the bruss sprouts pulls out a tiny hidden jar of BELUGA CAVIAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets the crackers, a plate and a spoon and sits down the table next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can stand both of us being maudlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fixes several crackers, each with an appropriate doll of caviar on top, and puts the plate in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one solution to all this, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offers him one of the crackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could both get to work -- together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tentatively, Hitch accepts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tiresome little Hitchcock imitation I've been helping Whit finish is done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch remains quiet, delicately consuming his cracker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I suggest, for everyone's sake, we start whipping Psycho into shape tomorrow. You may not be the easiest man to live with but you know how to cut a picture better than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch puts the lid back on the caviar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of quick shots as the editing room comes to life

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITCH and editor GEORGE TOMASINI wait quietly like schoolboys, while Alma reviews the footage on the Moviola

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll need to cut those six or seven frames where she blinks after she's supposed to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've seen the footage a thousand times. She doesn't blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma gives him a look ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR ASSISTANTS are working on MOVIOLAS. Alma and Hitch w their way down the line, inspecting each new assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take thirty frames off the head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, the second take, the light is better on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only cut back to Janet once the car's already moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it tighter. The minute I lose one person I've lost the whole audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO PAIRS OF HANDS. Hitchcock's and Alma's. They work lik pair of twenty-year-olds at a pair of MOVIOLAS cutting th picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE LOOSENS -- to reveal George Tomasini has dozed off, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You imp. You got nudity in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her breasts are very large, dear. It was a challenge not to show them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Editor GEORGE TOMASINI works at the Moviola, sleeves roll up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. She did blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands with a pestering PR FLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going in there with Mr. Herrmann?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimmingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's saying it's a dog with fleas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Peggy can deny it the argument flares through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Absolutely not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard Herrmann is pressing his point hard with Hitchcoc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't want music in the shower murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what Alma and I talked about is really going to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This isn't Vertigo, Bernie. This is different. The images have to work on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't scare people just by going, "Boo!" You have to tell them what's coming, make them anticipate it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PR Flack shares a despairing look with Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God we've got Cinderfella for the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERNARD HERRMANN'S ICONIC SCORE RISES as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move across HITCH, ALMA, TOMASINI and PEGGY'S faces as they watch the Moviola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The impact of the music is instant and unimaginably power

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all moved. Gripped. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock looks down. Peggy is gripping his arm tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm never going to take a shower again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alma turns to him and Hitch nods slightly. Was that the tiniest acknowledgement that her instinct may have been right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock sits opposite him at the big conference table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I distinctly saw both the stabbing and the nudity. We're denying your seal, Mr. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take your opinion very seriously. But what you think you're seeing is purely informed by the power of suggestion. I assure you that once you view the final version with Mr. Herrmann's lovely, lyrical score...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "lyrical score" won't change my opinion. All that innuendo and half-naked groping -- really, Hitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if we had a word in private, Geoffrey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock gestures his staff out. Hitch moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a modest proposal to make. If you're willing to leave the shower sequence as it is, I will reshoot the opening love scene to your exact specifications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock reacts with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In fact, I'd welcome your personal supervision on the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock is more flattered than he'd care to admit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My specifications?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only audiences could fully appreciate how tirelessly you work to help us entertain them while protecting them from filth and indecency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shurlock studies Hitchcock's sphinx-like expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock and Peggy confer. John Gavin and Janet Leigh, wearing robes, chat while lying on a bed. Crew members wa impatiently. Peggy checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been harassing you since you announced this project, you invite him to the set, and he doesn't even show up? What did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I respected him. Deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy laughs. Now she understands.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, that is a wrap. Thank you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew starts breaking things down. The actors are baff Janet walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were reshooting the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need. The charade is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch holds out his arm for her and walks her back to the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, I wasn't that much of a monster to work with, was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers his hand and she shakes it, determined to be professional to the end.

dialogues.speaker: JANET LEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just hope I was sufficiently loyal to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worthy of a Purple Heart, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans in and gives him a peck on the cheek. A moment unexpected heaven that leaves Hitch speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away to her dressing room. Hitch watches as she steps inside and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment we hear a PIERCING SCREAM --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet recoils at the sight of A MRS. BATES PROTOTYPE "PRO MASK" grinning lewdly from her chair, and wearing one of Janet's brassieres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock peeks inside as crew members come running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind, I told Mrs. Bates she could have your dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't believe she's been caught out. She closes the d on everyone... and then after a moment SCREAMS AGAIN... b this time not out of shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch sweeps in. Lew is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have our seal from Shurlock's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, we lead the lambs to the slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch turns to Lew for the latest news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front office confirmed. They're only opening the movie in two theatres, as we suspected. And no premiere. If we don't get word of mouth we're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'd better get started. Peggy, take a memo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy whips out her steno pad.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to write a manual on exactly how to sell Psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOKLETS make the rounds on a conveyor-like contraption. the booklets are bound by swift-moving WORKERS, we see Hitchcock's photo on a cover and his "advice" to theater owners.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My first instruction to Theater Owners: Hire Pinkerton guards to strictly enforce our unique admission policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANAGER opens up his PSYCHO PROMOTIONAL HANDBOOK and st to read, totally baffled.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Furthermore, because Psycho is so terrifying and unique, the guards can help you deal with customers who run amok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager introduces the PINKERTON GUARDS to his equall bemused STAFF.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Post our special lobby clocks to remind audiences of the starting times for Psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He oversees as they hang a ridiculously large PSYCHO CLOC the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch's voice booms from LARGE SPEAKERS MOUNTED UNDER THE MARQUEE.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The manager of this fine motion picture theater has been advised not to allow anyone to enter the theater once Psycho begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN DOWN to the STAFF and GUARDS as they test out the RECORDED message that will be played for the ticket holde line. A couple of PASSERSBY listen, perplexed...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Should you be so foolish as to attempt to slip in by a side entrance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a fire escape or through a skylight, you will be ejected by brute force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch lays down the track into a large microphone while A watches from the recording desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More playful, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of life-size HITCHCOCK STANDEES are carried in thro the door one by one. Posters are hung in the theatre lobb The letters hoisted up and hung on the marquee outside.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "To further emphasize the sheer, unrelenting shock and suspense of Psycho, right after the closing title "THE END," we strongly recommend that you close your house curtains over the screen for a full thirty seconds."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the theatre, the manager makes sure the CURTAINS o and close correctly then turns to face the vast, empty auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: "By doing so, the horror of Psycho will be indelibly etched in the mind and heart of your audience."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He anxiously surveys the hundreds of seats that will have be filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Barney Balaban is reading Hitchcock's publicity manua the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Absolutely never, ever will I allow anything to follow Psycho -- no previews of coming attractions, no newsreel, no short subject and certainly no double- feature. Sincerely, and, emphatically, Alfred Hitchcock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balaban shuts the pamphlet. Silence. Then turns to the st faced board members :

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At the end of the day, it's a minor Hitchcock movie. One week, and it'll be gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the pamphlet into the trash.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY BALABAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HITCH AND ALMA'S SILENT TENSE EXPRESSIONS as they driv through the frenetic madness that typifies Times Square, 1960.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DAZZLING MARQUEE for "ALFRED HITCHCOCK'S PSYCHO." The c pulls up. Hitch and Alma step out. There's a long line of people outside the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least there are some people here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hitch's nerves are hardly soothed. The people in line start to notice the Hitchcocks...is it really them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes over to greet them with the THEATRE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go through the side entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the theatre manager ushers them through the side alley

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way, Mr. and Mrs. Hitchcock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock turns to Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for the gallows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is tense as people hurry to their seats. L greets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've roped off some seats for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll join you in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Alma's look.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to double check the print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, darling. I'll save you a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew escorts Alma and Peggy into the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soothing whir of the projector as Hitchcock stands ne to it... but the sound of the audience below TITTERING NERVOUSLY is anything but reassuring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) But they're laughing too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers down through the tiny window but can't see a blo thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch inches open the door and PEERS THROUGH THE CRACK at audience but now he can't read them. Are they gripped wit suspense -- or do they just hate it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the lobby we see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he closes the door and leans back against the wall of empty corridor. A scared, lonely, corpulent figure. Total powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing for him to do but wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the foyer, a spotty young THEATRE EMPLOYEE sweeps ticket stubs and empties ashtrays, quietly going about hi business, entirely oblivious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he grips the railing. This is taking far too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- finally -- the sweetest sound in the world A BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon the WHOLE AUDIENCE SCREAMS IN TERROR... then breaks LAUGHTER again... nervous laughter this time, the best ki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he gestures with his hands, a conductor leading his orchestra, raising them up again as the audience STARTS SCREAMING AGAIN right on cue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dam breaks and all the pent-up emotion floods out. leaving only relief and satisfaction... and making way fo smile... the largest of his whole career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch, Alma and Peggy are led out into the foyer by the theatre manager. There are still SCREAMS in the theatre a the show continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew can be seen on the phone in the theatre manager's off in the background as Hitch, Alma and Peggy walk past the of ticket buyers to get to the front doors. There is grea excitement now as more and more people recognize the Hitchcocks...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WAITING ON LINE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, how does it end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised Mother I wouldn't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets a laugh. Hitchcock walks alongside the Theater Manager who's not going to miss out on having his own mom with the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hitchcock, what do I do now that my wife won't take a shower after seeing your movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have her dry-cleaned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter as Lew appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with Balaban. I couldn't resist telling him we're sold out for the next two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said "Tell Hitch congratulations. A well deserved triumph as we always knew."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "As we always knew..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two friends a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean I can take the weekend off now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitch playfully shrugs, "we'll see".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Hithcock but there are photographers outside. They heard you were here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theatre manager ushers them towards the exit doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few photographers snap Hitch as he emerges and heads pa the line of ticket buyers towards the waiting car. Hitchc gestures for Alma to take her place next to him instead o behind him. She shyly waves him away but eventually, and appreciatively, relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the flashbulbs start to POP --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be the biggest hit of your career, Alfred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our career, Alma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks into her eyes with nothing but deep, intense gratitude and joy. As more flashbulbs pop --

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've realized I'll never be able to find a Hitchcock blonde as beautiful as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do realize I've been waiting decades to hear you say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a gentle peck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that, madame, is why they call me "The Master of Suspense"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps her into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a utilitarian institutionalized dining room. Severa nonviolent INMATES eat at different round tables around t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ATTENDANT watches, and an ORDERLY mops the floor (ther are NO female patients nor staff members.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is at a table with two other patients, including a soft spoken older man, CHET. Ed is heavier, his hair is whiter and he is much more at ease than we've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Attendant) Guess what I'm doing this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claudine and I are driving to Chicago with her folks to see that Psycho movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Attendant pulls the orderly aside, and whispers to hi nodding toward Ed. The Orderly's jaw drops! It is the coo thing he's ever heard. He looks at Ed like he's a movie s Meanwhile, Ed yawns, content. Utterly oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're the happiest guy I've ever known, Ed. How you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you. You live your life, and it's unbearable sometimes but there's this secret, Chet; a big secret no one else knows or wants to tell... (he leans a little closer) ... there is a God and he's so big and powerful, he doesn't always remember you're there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a huge bite blueberry pie.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... but if you can get his attention and he sees you're suffering, he'll notice and he'll take care of you. My mother used to tell me -- she's passed, God bless her -- the one thing God truly loves and understands is suffering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a long drink of milk.

dialogues.speaker: ED GEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After all, he invented it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan to discover HITCHCOCK has been watching all this. turns to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, gentle viewer, Psycho -- the picture everyone predicted would bring me to wrack and ruin -- was such a hit that Alma and I got to... Well, let's just say that we got to keep our house -- and the swimming pool. And the same critics who despised it went on to call it one of my greatest achievements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a CIGAR and wanders towards the exit doors.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course for me, it was just another "moo-vie."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he strolls through the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and seamlessly appears in the beautifully tended garde as if having walked through a portal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know what they say in Hollywood: "You're only as good as your last picture." So, now, if you'll excuse me, I must toddle off to begin the exhaustive search for my next project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his cigar towards something we don't yet see

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately I find myself once again bereft of all inspiration. I do hope something comes along soon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alights on his cigar tip and FLAPS its wings. Hitchcock c resist blowing a sadistic plume of smoke at the bird whic promptly flies away. He gives the camera a final characteristically deadpan look...

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distinctive THEME TUNE to his TV show starts up and H toddles back up the front lawn and toward the terrace, wh Alma can be seen laying out a delicious healthy lunch...
